skill.name: lamindb
skill.description: This skill should be used when working with LaminDB, an open-source data framework for biology that makes data queryable, traceable, reproducible, and FAIR. Use when managing biological datasets (scRNA-seq, spatial, flow cytometry, etc.), tracking computational workflows, curating and validating data with biological ontologies, building data lakehouses, or ensuring data lineage and reproducibility in biological research. Covers data management, annotation, ontologies (genes, cell types, diseases, tissues), schema validation, integrations with workflow managers (Nextflow, Snakemake) and MLOps platforms (W&B, MLflow), and deployment strategies.
skill.summary: This skill should be used when working with LaminDB, an open-source data framework for biology that ...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: This skill contains ONLY markdown documentation files for LaminDB, a legitimate open-source biological data management framework. All 570 static findings are FALSE POSITIVES because they detect patterns in documentation examples, not executable code. The skill has no Python files, no scripts, and poses no security risk.

content.value_statement: LaminDB makes biological data queryable, traceable, and reproducible. Use it to manage datasets like scRNA-seq and flow cytometry, track computational workflows, validate annotations with biological ontologies, and ensure data lineage from raw data through analysis.
actual_capabilities: Track data lineage from raw inputs through analysis to results using Artifacts, Runs, and Transforms
Query and filter biological datasets by metadata, features, and ontology terms
Validate and standardize annotations using biological ontologies (genes, cell types, diseases, tissues)
Integrate with workflow managers (Nextflow, Snakemake) and MLOps platforms (W&B, MLflow)
Manage cloud storage (AWS S3, Google Cloud Storage) with automatic caching and versioning
Create schemas for data validation and curate datasets with DataFrameCurator and AnnDataCurator
limitations: Requires understanding of biological data formats (AnnData, Parquet, Zarr)
Cloud storage setup requires valid AWS or GCP credentials
Ontology standardization requires network access to download public ontologies

use_cases.title: Track scRNA-seq analysis
use_cases.description: Load single-cell RNA-seq data, validate cell type annotations against ontology, track pipeline execution and save validated datasets with full lineage.

use_cases.title: Build queryable data lakehouse
use_cases.description: Register multiple experiments, annotate with metadata features, query across all datasets, and stream large files without loading into memory.

use_cases.title: Integrate ML pipelines
use_cases.description: Connect LaminDB with W&B or MLflow, track model training data, link artifacts to experiment runs, and ensure reproducible model deployment.

prompt_templates.title: Basic usage
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me set up LaminDB for my single-cell RNA-seq project. Show me how to initialize an instance, load my AnnData file, and track the analysis workflow.

prompt_templates.title: Data validation
prompt_templates.prompt: My scRNA-seq data has cell type annotations in obs['cell_type']. Validate these against the Cell Ontology, standardize any mismatched terms, and save the curated artifact with proper ontology linkage.

prompt_templates.title: Lineage tracking
prompt_templates.prompt: Set up LaminDB to track my Nextflow pipeline. Show how to use ln.track() at the start and ln.finish() at the end to capture the full provenance from raw FASTQ files through alignment to count matrices.

prompt_templates.title: Query across datasets
prompt_templates.prompt: I have multiple batches of processed data stored in LaminDB. Query all artifacts where tissue='PBMC' and condition='treated', then return their keys and creation dates in a DataFrame.

output_examples.input: Set up LaminDB to track my scRNA-seq analysis with cell type ontology validation
output: Initialized LaminDB instance with local SQLite storage
Standardized 8 cell type terms against ontology

best_practices: Use ln.track() at the start of every analysis to automatically capture computational lineage
Validate data against ontologies before extensive analysis to catch annotation errors early
Structure artifact keys hierarchically like 'project/experiment/batch/file.h5ad' for organized querying
anti_patterns: Loading large files without filtering by metadata first - use query filters to avoid memory issues
Modifying data without creating a new version - use built-in versioning instead of new keys
Skipping ontology standardization - inconsistent terminology breaks queryability and reproducibility

faq.question: What is LaminDB?
faq.answer: LaminDB is an open-source data framework for biology that makes datasets queryable, traceable, reproducible, and FAIR through a Python API.

faq.question: How does lineage tracking work?
faq.answer: Use ln.track() at analysis start and ln.finish() at end. LaminDB captures what code, inputs, and parameters produced each output artifact.

faq.question: What biological ontologies are supported?
faq.answer: Genes (Ensembl), Proteins (UniProt), Cell types (CL), Tissues (Uberon), Diseases (Mondo), Phenotypes (HPO), Pathways (GO), and more via Bionty.

faq.question: Can I use LaminDB locally?
faq.answer: Yes. Start with local SQLite for development. Scale to cloud storage and PostgreSQL when ready for production or team collaboration.

faq.question: What data formats are supported?
faq.answer: DataFrames, AnnData (single-cell), MuData (multi-modal), SpatialData, Parquet, Zarr, TileDB-SOMA, and any file format.

faq.question: How does cloud storage work?
faq.answer: Initialize with s3:// or gs:// paths. Artifacts sync automatically. Cached locally for performance with transparent cloud access.
